title-group.article-title: Pulmonary cytology: Pearls and pitfalls of non‐neoplastic mimics of lung cancer

author-notes.corresp: *Correspondence María D. Lozano, Department of Pathology, University of Navarra, Avenida Pio XII, 36, Pamplona 31008, Navarra, Spain. Email: mdlozano@unav.es

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Lung cancer continues to be the leading cause of cancer‐related mortality, with cytologic samples often serving as the primary diagnostic tool. However, differentiating between benign and malignant processes in lung cytology can be difficult because various non‐neoplastic conditions closely resemble malignant lesions, which may lead to misdiagnosis. This review offers nine essential tips to help cytopathologists prevent false‐positive diagnoses of malignancy in non‐neoplastic processes. By examining common non‐neoplastic entities that can mimic lung malignancies, this review emphasizes their key cytomorphologic features and distinguishing characteristics. The authors stress the importance of a thorough clinical and radiologic context, slide background evaluation, and identification of cytomorphologic features for an accurate diagnosis of these mimics. The objective of this review was to enhance diagnostic accuracy and prevent misdiagnosis, thereby improving patient management in lung cancer cytopathology.

The authors provide nine tips for recognizing the most common non‐neoplastic entities that can cytologically mimic lung cancer, emphasizing their cytomorphologic features and key distinguishing characteristics. Potential sources of diagnostic errors also are examined, and strategies are proposed to avoid them.

p.mixed-citation: RobledanoR, ArguetaA, LabianoT, LozanoMD. Pulmonary cytology: Pearls and pitfalls of non‐neoplastic mimics of lung cancer. Cancer Cytopathol. 2025;e70039. doi:10.1002/cncy.7003940900401PMC12406978

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancer‐related death, 1 , 2 and cytologic samples are frequently the only available specimens for diagnosis. 3 , 4 , 5 , 6 , 7 , 8 , 9 Distinguishing between benign and malignant processes is crucial and often challenging in cytology. 10 Furthermore, several benign conditions can radiologically and morphologically mimic lung malignancies, leading to potential misdiagnosis. 11 Pathologists must recognize key features to distinguish these potential malignant mimics from real malignant tumors to avoid false‐positive or false‐negative results.

This review outlines nine tips for recognizing the most common non‐neoplastic entities that can cytologically mimic lung cancer, emphasizing their cytomorphologic features and key distinguishing characteristics. The text also examines potential sources of diagnostic errors and proposes strategies to avoid them (Table 1).

list-item.p: Clinical and radiologic correlation is critical for assessing specimen adequacy and interpreting cytologic findings accurately.
Begin with low‐magnification review to assess overall cellularity and background before committing to a definitive diagnosis.
Reactive type II pneumocytes can mimic adenocarcinoma; look for preserved nuclear‐to‐cytoplasmic (N:C) ratio, cytoplasmic vacuoles, and a spectrum of atypia.
Cilia and terminal bars signify benign bronchial epithelium; always check cells with high N:C ratios for these features to avoid overcalling as malignant.
Goblet cell hyperplasia may mimic mucinous adenocarcinoma; correlate with imaging and look for clean background, smooth nuclear membranes, and fine chromatin.

Chemotherapy and radiation can cause cytologic atypia; cytomegaly with normal to only mildly increased N:C ratio, smudgy chromatin, and low mitotic activity are clues to the reactive nature of the atypia.
Squamous metaplasia may mimic squamous cell carcinoma—review for benign cytomorphology and correlate with clinical context and imaging to avoid overdiagnosis.
Basal (or reserve) cell hyperplasia consists of cells that are smaller than those of small cell lung cancer, with uniform nuclei, low proliferative activity, and no necrosis or crush artifact.

Liquid‐based cytology can alter cell appearance. Be cautious because small cell lung cancer may appear smaller and more dispersed in liquid‐based cytology samples relative to direct smears; validate immunocytochemical stains accordingly.

sec.title: INITIAL ASSESSMENT OF A LUNG CYTOLOGY SAMPLE
Tip 1. Clinical and radiologic information is essential for ensuring and establishing specimen adequacy
sec.p: In respiratory cytopathology, specimen adequacy is crucial. 12 , 13 Familiarity with the radiologic features of the lesion targeted for biopsy can guide the cytologist's expectations for what to expect during rapid on‐site evaluation. Figure 1 exemplifies what to expect from the radiologic findings from a fine‐needle aspiration biopsy. It is also important to understand that there are various techniques for obtaining respiratory samples, each with different levels of sensitivity and specificity. Clinical correlation is also helpful because smoking, asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, exposure to certain substances, prior illnesses, and drugs/medications can alter the typical cytomorphology of non‐neoplastic cells. 10 , 11 , 14

caption.p: Ensuring a correct sampling and representativeness. (A) Thoracic computed tomography scan showing a mediastinal mass and parenchymal nodule on the right lung. (B) Endobronchial ultrasound‐guided fine‐needle aspiration with presence of the needle inside the pathologic lesion. Papanicolaou stained.

sec.title: Tip 2. Low‐magnification assessment of overall cellularity is critical
sec.p: The background material in a pulmonary cytology sample can serve as a potential clue for diagnosis. After obtaining clinical and radiologic history, evaluate the overall cellularity and determine whether the specimen is representative of the targeted lesion. 15 , 16 It is advisable to avoid a definitive malignant diagnosis based on a low‐cellularity sample. 15 A definite diagnosis should also be avoided in suboptimally prepared samples, including those with poor smearing, inadequate fixation, artifacts, obscuring inflammation, or other background material. 17

sec.title: Tip 3. Recognize features to help distinguish reactive pneumocytes from adenocarcinoma
sec.p: In the setting of lung injury—as can be seen in infarcts, organizing pneumonia, or acute respiratory distress syndrome—reactive proliferation of type II pneumocytes can mimic lung adenocarcinoma. 18 Reactive pneumocytes are most often seen in bronchoalveolar lavage and bronchial washing specimens. 10 Cytomorphologic features of reactive pneumocytes that overlap with those of lung adenocarcinoma include nuclear enlargement (albeit with a preserved nucleus‐to‐cytoplasm [N:C] ratio), hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular cellular membranes, macronuclei, and mitotic figures. 10 , 19 Also like adenocarcinoma, reactive pneumocytes can manifest on cytology preparations as single cells, small clusters, or sheets. Binucleation and multinucleation can also occur. 18 The cytoplasm tends to be cyanophilic (Giemsa stain) and ranges from finely vacuolated to distended by one or more large vacuoles. 19

sec.title: Tip 4. When evaluating epithelial cells with a high N:C ratio, always double‐check for the presence of cilia and terminal bars: These structures, when present, strongly support a benign process and can help prevent false‐positive diagnoses
sec.p: Bronchial epithelial cells may exhibit reactive hyperplasia and atypia in response to chronic airway injury or irritation, including asthma, infections (e.g., tuberculosis, viral), smoking, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, toxin exposure, and effects of radiation, chemotherapy, or instrumentation. 11 , 29 , 30 Cytologic samples in these settings can be hypercellular and show cohesive sheets, papillary clusters, or three‐dimensional groups of cells with a streaming pattern. The cells can display a high N:C ratio, hyperchromatic nuclei, macronucleoli, and multinucleation, with nuclear features in multinucleated cells typically resembling those of single cells. 21 Mild nuclear molding and a few mucus‐producing cells may also be seen. The background can range from clean to inflammatory, depending on the underlying process. These reactive changes may closely mimic adenocarcinoma; however, the presence of cilia and terminal bars is a key cytologic feature of benign bronchial epithelium. Although these structures may be obscured by degenerative changes, they are important to identify when present because they support a benign interpretation and help avoid false‐positive diagnoses.

caption.p: Key cytologic features differentiating between benign reactive atypia and well differentiated adenocarcinoma.

tr.td: Fewer and smaller intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions
Large and more prominent intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions
Presence of terminal bar and cilia
Absence of terminal bar and cilia

caption.p: Summary: Non‐neoplastic mimics of lung adenocarcinoma.

list-item.p: Cytologic changes related to chemotherapy or radiotherapy

caption.p: A Papanicolaou‐stained smear obtained by endobronchial ultrasound‐guided fine‐needle aspiration showing crowded, three‐dimensional groups of tightly packed cells, a high nuclear‐to‐cytoplasmic ratio, and hyperchromatic nuclei (original magnification ×5).

Papanicolaou‐stained smears obtained by endobronchial ultrasound‐guided fine‐needle aspiration showing crowded groups cells with high nuclear‐to‐cytoplasmic ratios, hyperchromatic nuclei, abundant cytoplasm, and the presence of cilia and terminal bars on the edges of the groups (original magnification ×40).

Papanicolaou‐stained smears obtained by endobronchial ultrasound‐guided fine‐needle aspiration. (A) Reactive bronchial epithelium. Note the presence of occasionally preserved polarity, small nuclei, fewer and smaller intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions, smaller nucleoli, and terminal bars and cilia. (B) Well differentiated adenocarcinoma. Note the presence of larger groups of cells; loss of cellular polarity; crowded cell groups; larger, more hyperchromatic nuclei; large and more prominent intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions; and larger nucleoli and the absence of terminal bar and cilia (original magnification ×40 in A and B).

sec.title: Tip 5. Beware of misdiagnosing goblet cell hyperplasia as mucinous adenocarcinoma
sec.p: Goblet cell hyperplasia may be seen in the lower airway of patients with smoking history and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, 31 and it can mimic primary or metastatic mucinous adenocarcinoma, as illustrated in Figures 5 and 6. In such cases, accurate clinical and radiologic correlation is essential to avoid misdiagnosis. Features that support goblet cell hyperplasia over mucinous adenocarcinoma include the absence of a mass‐forming lesion on imaging, a clean background on cytologic preparations, smooth nuclear membranes, fine chromatin, and inconspicuous nucleoli. 10 , 32

caption.p: Well differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma. Three‐dimensional clusters of uniform cells show a low nuclear‐to‐cytoplasmic ratio, large cytoplasmic vacuoles, irregular nuclear membranes, and inconspicuous nucleoli. Papanicolaou‐stained smears from an endobronchial ultrasound‐guided fine‐needle aspiration.

Well differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma. Three‐dimensional clusters of uniform cells show a low nuclear‐to‐cytoplasmic ratio, large cytoplasmic vacuoles, irregular nuclear membranes, and inconspicuous nucleoli. Note the presence of traces of extracellular mucin on the background. Papanicolaou‐stained smears from an endobronchial ultrasound‐guided fine‐needle aspiration (original magnification ×40 in A, ×20 in B).

sec.title: Tip 6. Cytologic changes related to chemotherapy or radiotherapy may exhibit marked atypia but should not be mistaken for malignancy
NON‐NEOPLASTIC MIMICS OF LUNG SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA
Tip 7. Distinguishing squamous metaplasia from lung squamous cell carcinoma
sec.p: Squamous metaplasia can occur as a reparative change in the setting of airway irritation and injury. 10 , 21 , 22 , 34 Cytologic features that can masquerade as lung squamous cell carcinoma include three‐dimensional cell clusters, nuclear enlargement, macronucleoli, and a high N:C ratio. In selected cases, keratinization and reactive or degenerative nuclear atypia may be seen. 35 Features that can be helpful for distinguishing benign squamous metaplasia from lung squamous cell carcinoma are summarized in Table 4. Figures 7 and 8 illustrate examples of these entities (Table 5).

caption.p: Key cytologic features differentiating between benign reactive atypia and squamous cell carcinoma. a

fn.p: Adapted from The Art and Science of Cytopathology; DeMay 2011. 18

caption.p: A Papanicolaou‐stained smear obtained by endobronchial ultrasound‐guided fine‐needle aspiration. Note the presence of groups and single squamous cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, uniform nuclear size and shape, absent nucleoli, and evenly distributed chromatin (original magnification ×10).

(A,B) Squamous cell carcinoma on a bronchoalveolar lavage sample. Papanicolaou‐stained liquid‐based cytology preparation showing the presence of single cells with dense basophilic cytoplasm, irregular nuclei, hyperchromasia, and a high nuclear‐to‐cytoplasmic ratio on an inflammatory background.
Summary: Non‐neoplastic mimics of squamous cell carcinoma.

list-item.p: Cavitary lesions and infections (mimicking tumor necrosis)

sec.title: NON‐NEOPLASTIC MIMICS OF SMALL CELL LUNG CARCINOMA
sec.p: The cytologic diagnosis of small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) is often straightforward. However, cytopathologists must be aware of reactive processes involving cells from the bronchial wall that can cytologically overlap with SCLC.

sec.title: Tip 8. Be aware of two benign mimics of SCLC
sec.p: Hyperplasia of immature basal or reserve cells present at the base of the pseudostratified respiratory epithelium can be seen in the setting of airway injury, either in exfoliative bronchial specimens or as contaminants from endobronchial ultrasound‐guided fine‐needle aspiration biopsies. Cytologically, reserve cells present as aggregates of small, lymphocyte‐sized cells with uniform, dark, round nuclei; occasional molding; and scant cytoplasm. 16 , 21 Ciliated cells may be seen in the proximity of these cells. The Ki‐67 proliferation index is usually low. 36 Compared with SCLC (in which the cells are typically from two to three times the size of lymphocytes), reserve cells are smaller and lack significant nuclear pleomorphism, mitotic activity, apoptosis, or crush artifact. 21 , 28

Lymphocytes from follicular bronchiolitis can cytologically mimic SCLC or even lymphoma. In such cases, flow cytometry and immunocytochemistry are helpful for establishing cellular lineage as well as the polyclonality of lymphoid cells. 27 , 33
Table 6 summarizes the cytologic features that help differentiate contaminant reserve cells and lymphocytes from follicular bronchiolitis and SCLC; some examples are shown in Figures 9 and 10.

caption.p: Key cytologic features differentiating between contaminant reserve cells from follicular bronchitis in small cell lung carcinoma.
Summary: Non‐neoplastic mimics of small cell lung cancer.

Reserve cell hyperplasia. (A) A Papanicolaou‐stained smear obtained by endobronchial ultrasound‐guided fine‐needle aspiration with the presence of tightly, packed three‐dimensional aggregates of small cells with uniform, dark, round nuclei; occasional molding; and scant cytoplasm that occasionally may present in association with ciliated bronchial cells (original magnification ×40). (B) A Papanicolaou‐stained smear obtained by endobronchial ultrasound‐guided fine‐needle aspiration showcasing similar features as in A (original magnification ×40). (C,D) The cells exhibited nuclear staining for P40 immunocytochemistry.

Small cell lung carcinoma. (A,B) A liquid‐based cytology preparation obtained by endobronchial ultrasound‐guided fine‐needle aspiration (Papanicolaou stained). Highly cellular smears showing a polymorphous cell population composed of occasional aggregates and numerous, small, single cells. Note the presence of high nuclear‐to‐cytoplasmic ratios, scant cytoplasm, irregular nuclear membranes, occasional molding, and granular chromatin (original magnification ×5 in A, ×20 in B). (C) Membranous immunocytochemical staining against synaptophysin.

Small cell carcinoma in liquid‐based cytology preparations. Note the presence of small clusters or small single cells with monotonous appearance, an absence of nucleoli, and a clear background (Papanicolaou stained).

sec.title: Tip 9. The cytologic preparation type can contribute to challenges in distinguishing from benign mimics
sec.p:
Compared with direct smears, liquid‐based cytology (LBC) offers several advantages, such as reducing the unsatisfactory rate of specimens, eliminating obscuring elements, facilitating screening, and ensuring excellent preservation. 15 However, it is important to keep the following caveats in mind to prevent misdiagnosis of SCLC in LBC:
SCLC cells often appear smaller in LBC preparations compared with direct smears. 14
SCLC can present in LBC preparations as single cells or small clusters, 37 as shown in Figure 11.
As with all cytology preparations, immunocytochemistry on LBC specimens should be validated (Table 7). 38

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Non‐neoplastic entities can cytologically mimic malignant lung lesions, posing a risk for misdiagnosis and inappropriate management. Familiarity with these cytologic mimics is essential. Accurate identification relies on integrating clinical and radiologic context with careful assessment of cytomorphological features.

sec.title: CONFLICT OF INTEREST STATEMENT
sec.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

sec.title: DATA AVAILABILITY STATEMENT
sec.p: The data that support the findings from this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.
